title: Tony Randall
text:
Anthony Leonard Randall (born Aryeh Leonard Rosenberg; February 26, 1920 – May 17, 2004) was an American comedian, actor, game show panelist and singer. He is best known for his role as Felix Unger in a <a href="The%20Odd%20Couple%20%281970%20TV%20series%29">television adaptation</a> of the 1965 play "<a href="The%20Odd%20Couple%20%28play%29">The Odd Couple</a>" by <a href="Neil%20Simon">Neil Simon</a>. In a career spanning six decades, Randall received six <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award">Golden Globe Award</a> nominations and six <a href="Primetime%20Emmy%20Award">Primetime Emmy Award</a> nominations, winning one.
Biography.
Early years.
Randall was born to a <a href="Jews">Jewish</a> family in <a href="Tulsa%2C%20Oklahoma">Tulsa</a>, <a href="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>, the son of Julia (née Finston) and Mogscha Rosenberg, an art and antiques dealer. He attended <a href="Central%20High%20School%20%28Tulsa%2C%20Oklahoma%29">Tulsa Central High School</a>.
Randall attended <a href="Northwestern%20University">Northwestern University</a> for a year before going to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> to study at the <a href="Neighborhood%20Playhouse%20School%20of%20the%20Theatre">Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre</a>. He studied under <a href="Sanford%20Meisner">Sanford Meisner</a> and choreographer <a href="Martha%20Graham">Martha Graham</a>. Randall worked as an announcer at radio station <a href="WTAG">WTAG</a> in <a href="Worcester%2C%20Massachusetts">Worcester</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>. As Anthony Randall, he starred with <a href="Jane%20Cowl">Jane Cowl</a> in <a href="George%20Bernard%20Shaw">George Bernard Shaw</a>'s "<a href="Candida%20%28play%29">Candida</a>" and <a href="Ethel%20Barrymore">Ethel Barrymore</a> in <a href="Emlyn%20Williams">Emlyn Williams</a>'s "<a href="The%20Corn%20Is%20Green">The Corn Is Green</a>".
Randall served for four years with the <a href="Signal%20Corps%20%28United%20States%20Army%29">United States Army Signal Corps</a> in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, including work at the codebreaking <a href="Signal%20Intelligence%20Service">Signal Intelligence Service</a>. After the war, he worked at the <a href="Olney%20Theatre">Olney Theatre</a> in <a href="Montgomery%20County%2C%20Maryland">Montgomery County</a>, <a href="Maryland">Maryland</a> before heading back to New York City.
One of Randall's first jobs was playing "Reggie" on the long-running 1940s radio series "<a href="I%20Love%20a%20Mystery">I Love a Mystery</a>". 
Broadway.
In 1946, Randall was cast as one of the brothers in a touring production of <a href="Katharine%20Cornell">Katharine Cornell</a>'s revival of "<a href="The%20Barretts%20of%20Wimpole%20Street">The Barretts of Wimpole Street</a>".
Randall appeared on Broadway in Cornell's production of "<a href="Antony%20and%20Cleopatra">Antony and Cleopatra</a>" (1947–48) with Cornell, <a href="Charlton%20Heston">Charlton Heston</a>, and <a href="Maureen%20Stapleton">Maureen Stapleton</a>, and in "<a href="Caesar%20and%20Cleopatra%20%28play%29">Caesar and Cleopatra</a>" (1949–50) with <a href="Cedric%20Hardwicke">Cedric Hardwicke</a> and <a href="Lilli%20Palmer">Lilli Palmer</a>. Randall began appearing on television, notably episodes of "<a href="One%20Man%27s%20Family">One Man's Family</a>".
"Mister Peepers".
Randall's first major television role was as history teacher Harvey Weskit in "<a href="Mister%20Peepers">Mister Peepers</a>" (1952–1955). He continued to guest-star on other shows such as "<a href="The%20Gulf%20Playhouse">The Gulf Playhouse</a>" (directed by <a href="Arthur%20Penn">Arthur Penn</a>), "<a href="The%20Pepsi-Cola%20Playhouse">The Pepsi-Cola Playhouse</a>", "<a href="Kraft%20Theatre">Kraft Theatre</a>", "<a href="The%20Motorola%20Television%20Hour">The Motorola Television Hour</a>", "<a href="Armstrong%20Circle%20Theatre">Armstrong Circle Theatre</a>", "<a href="Studio%20One%20in%20Hollywood">Studio One in Hollywood</a>", "Appointment with Adventure", and "<a href="The%20Philco%20Television%20Playhouse">The Philco-Goodyear Television Playhouse</a>".
Randall replaced <a href="Gig%20Young">Gig Young</a> in the Broadway hit "<a href="Oh%2C%20Men%21%20Oh%2C%20Women%21">Oh, Men! Oh, Women!</a>" (1954).
"Inherit the Wind".
Randall's first major role in a Broadway hit was in "<a href="Inherit%20the%20Wind%20%28play%29">Inherit the Wind</a>" (1955–57), portraying newspaperman E. K. Hornbeck (based on real-life cynic <a href="H.%20L.%20Mencken">H. L. Mencken</a>), alongside <a href="Ed%20Begley">Ed Begley</a> and <a href="Paul%20Muni">Paul Muni</a>. On television he appeared in "Heaven Will Protect the Working Girl" (1956), co-written by Neil Simon. He also guest-starred on "<a href="The%20Alcoa%20Hour">The Alcoa Hour</a>".
Film star.
Randall's success in "Inherit the Wind" led to film offers and his first significant big-screen role in "<a href="Oh%2C%20Men%21%20Oh%2C%20Women%21">Oh, Men! Oh, Women!</a>" (1957) for <a href="20th%20Century%20Fox">20th Century Fox</a>, which promoted Randall to stardom with "<a href="Will%20Success%20Spoil%20Rock%20Hunter%3F">Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?</a>" (1957) alongside <a href="Jayne%20Mansfield">Jayne Mansfield</a>. He played one of the leads in "<a href="No%20Down%20Payment">No Down Payment</a>" (1957).
In 1958, Randall played the leading role in the Broadway <a href="musical%20comedy">musical comedy</a> "<a href="Oh%2C%20Captain%21">Oh, Captain!</a>", taking on a role originated on film by <a href="Alec%20Guinness">Alec Guinness</a>. The show was a financial failure, but Randall received a <a href="Tony%20Award">Tony Award</a> nomination for his dance turn with prima ballerina <a href="Alexandra%20Danilova">Alexandra Danilova</a>.
Randall appeared in "<a href="Westinghouse%20Desilu%20Playhouse">Westinghouse Desilu Playhouse</a>", "<a href="Goodyear%20Theatre">Goodyear Theatre</a>", "<a href="The%20United%20States%20Steel%20Hour">The United States Steel Hour</a>", "<a href="NBC%20Sunday%20Showcase">Sunday Showcase</a>" and "<a href="Playhouse%2090">Playhouse 90</a>".
Continuing success.
Randall co-starred with <a href="Debbie%20Reynolds">Debbie Reynolds</a> in "<a href="The%20Mating%20Game%20%28film%29">The Mating Game</a>" (1959) at <a href="MGM">MGM</a>. He appeared in the hit film "<a href="Pillow%20Talk%20%28film%29">Pillow Talk</a>" (1959) supporting <a href="Doris%20Day">Doris Day</a> and <a href="Rock%20Hudson">Rock Hudson</a>; he would reunite with Day and Hudson for two more films.
He starred in an NBC-TV special, "The Secret of Freedom", which was filmed during the summer of 1959 in <a href="Mount%20Holly%2C%20New%20Jersey">Mount Holly, New Jersey</a>, and broadcast on the network during the fall of 1959 and again in early 1960. On TV he was also in "<a href="The%20Man%20in%20the%20Moon%20%281960%20film%29">The Man in the Moon</a>" (1960), co-written by <a href="Mel%20Brooks">Mel Brooks</a>.
Randall was top-billed in MGM's "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Huckleberry%20Finn%20%281960%20film%29">The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn</a>" (1960). He had a "Pillow Talk"-style support role in "<a href="Let%27s%20Make%20Love">Let's Make Love</a>" (1960) with <a href="Marilyn%20Monroe">Marilyn Monroe</a> and <a href="Yves%20Montand">Yves Montand</a> and "<a href="Lover%20Come%20Back%20%281961%20film%29">Lover Come Back</a>" (1961) with Hudson and Day. Randall continued to guest on TV shows including "<a href="General%20Electric%20Theater">General Electric Theater</a>" and "<a href="Checkmate%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">Checkmate</a>". In 1961, Randall played a highly dramatic role in "Hangover," an episode of "<a href="The%20Alfred%20Hitchcock%20Hour">The Alfred Hitchcock Hour</a>" in which he portrayed an alcoholic business executive who strangles his wife in a drunken rage. He starred in a TV adaptation of "<a href="Arsenic%20%26amp%3B%20Old%20Lace">Arsenic & Old Lace</a>" (1962), and had big-screen leading roles in "<a href="Boys%27%20Night%20Out%20%28film%29">Boys' Night Out</a>" (1962) and "<a href="Island%20of%20Love%20%281963%20film%29">Island of Love</a>" (1963).
Randall starred as nearly all of the leading characters in the 1964 classic film "<a href="7%20Faces%20of%20Dr.%20Lao">7 Faces of Dr. Lao</a>", which was based on "<a href="The%20Circus%20of%20Dr.%20Lao">The Circus of Dr. Lao</a>" by <a href="Charles%20G.%20Finney">Charles G. Finney</a>. In addition to portraying and voicing the eponymous seven faces (Dr. Lao, the Abominable Snowman, Merlin, Appolonius of Tyana, The Giant Serpent, Pan, and Medusa), Randall also appeared without makeup in a two-second cameo as a solemn spectator in the crowd, for a total of eight roles in the film.
He played the lead in "<a href="The%20Brass%20Bottle%20%281964%20film%29">The Brass Bottle</a>" (1964) and made one last film with Hudson and Day, "<a href="Send%20Me%20No%20Flowers">Send Me No Flowers</a>" (1965). Randall took the lead in "<a href="Fluffy%20%281965%20film%29">Fluffy</a>" (1965), a comedy about a lion; "<a href="The%20Alphabet%20Murders">The Alphabet Murders</a>" (1965), playing <a href="Hercule%20Poirot">Hercule Poirot</a> for <a href="Frank%20Tashlin">Frank Tashlin</a>; "<a href="Our%20Man%20in%20Marrakesh">Our Man in Marrakesh</a>" (1966), as a secret agent; and "<a href="Hello%20Down%20There">Hello Down There</a>" (1969).
Randall returned to Broadway in "UTBU" (1966), which had only a short run. He appeared in the TV movie "<a href="The%20Littlest%20Angel">The Littlest Angel</a>" (1969) with <a href="Johnny%20Whitaker">Johnny Whitaker</a> and <a href="Fred%20Gwynne">Fred Gwynne</a>.
"The Odd Couple".
Randall returned to television in 1970 as Felix Unger in "<a href="The%20Odd%20Couple%20%281970%20TV%20series%29">The Odd Couple</a>", opposite <a href="Jack%20Klugman">Jack Klugman</a>, a role that lasted five years. The names of Felix's children on "The Odd Couple" were Edna and Leonard, named for Randall's sister and Randall himself.
In 1974, Randall and Klugman appeared in television spots endorsing a "<a href="Yahtzee">Yahtzee</a>" spinoff, "Challenge Yahtzee". They appeared in character as Felix and Oscar, and the TV spots were filmed on the same set as was "The Odd Couple".
During the series run, Randall took a small role in "<a href="Everything%20You%20Always%20Wanted%20to%20Know%20About%20Sex%2A%20%28%2ABut%20Were%20Afraid%20to%20Ask%29%20%28film%29">Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* (*But Were Afraid to Ask)</a>" (1972).
In 1973, he was hired to play the voice of Templeton the gluttonous rat in "<a href="Charlotte%27s%20Web%20%281973%20film%29">Charlotte's Web</a>", and recorded the part, but was replaced in the film by <a href="Paul%20Lynde">Paul Lynde</a>, as Randall's voice was perceived as too sophisticated by the director, who wanted Templeton to have a <a href="nasal%20voice">nasal voice</a>.
"The Tony Randall Show".
From 1976 to 1978, Randall starred in "<a href="The%20Tony%20Randall%20Show">The Tony Randall Show</a>", playing a Philadelphia judge. He had small roles in "<a href="Kate%20Bliss%20and%20the%20Ticker%20Tape%20Kid">Kate Bliss and the Ticker Tape Kid</a>" (1978), "<a href="Scavenger%20Hunt">Scavenger Hunt</a>" (1979), and "<a href="Foolin%27%20Around">Foolin' Around</a>" (1980).
"Love, Sidney".
Randall starred in "<a href="Love%2C%20Sidney">Love, Sidney</a>" from 1981 to 1983. In the TV movie that served as the latter show's pilot, "", Sidney Shorr was written as a <a href="homosexuality">gay</a> man, but his character's sexuality was made ambiguous when the series premiered. Randall refused to star in any more television shows, favoring the Broadway stage as his medium.
He did star in the TV movies "<a href="Sunday%20Drive%20%28film%29">Sunday Drive</a>" (1986) for Disney, "Save the Dog!" (1988), and "<a href="The%20Man%20in%20the%20Brown%20Suit">The Man in the Brown Suit</a>" (1989). From October 30 to November 2, 1987, Randall hosted the <a href="free%20preview">free preview</a> of <a href="HBO">HBO</a>'s short-lived premium channel <a href="HBO%23Festival">Festival</a>.
In 1989, Randall returned to Broadway as a replacement in "<a href="M.%20Butterfly">M. Butterfly</a>".
National Actors Theatre.
In 1991, Randall founded the <a href="National%20Actors%20Theatre">National Actors Theatre</a>, ultimately based at <a href="Pace%20University">Pace University</a> in New York City. Their productions included "<a href="The%20Crucible">The Crucible</a>" (1991), "A Little Hotel on the Side" (1992), "The Master Builder" (1992), "The Seagull" (1992), "Saint Joan" (1993), "Three Men on a Horse" (1993), "Timon of Athens" (1993), "The Government Inspector" (1993), "The Flowering Peach" (1994), "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" (1994), "The School for Scandal" (1995), "Inherit the Wind" (1996), and "The Gin Game" (1997). In 1997, he performed in "The Sunshine Boys" with Klugman to great success.
In September 1993, Randall and Klugman reunited in the <a href="CBS">CBS</a>-TV movie "," reprising their roles. The story began when, after Felix ruined plans for his daughter Edna's wedding, his wife Gloria threw him out of the house for 11 days, which left him no choice but to move back in with Oscar and to help him recover, getting him back in shape after throat cancer surgery had left his voice very raspy.
Randall's later stage productions included "Night Must Fall" (1999) and "Judgment at Nuremberg" (2001).
Periodically, he performed in stage revivals of "<a href="The%20Odd%20Couple%20%28play%29">The Odd Couple</a>" with Klugman, including a stint in London in 1996. Later film roles included "<a href="Fatal%20Instinct">Fatal Instinct</a>" (1994) and "<a href="Down%20with%20Love">Down with Love</a>" (2003).
Randall's last appearances on stage as an actor were in "The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui" (2002) and "Right You Are" (2003).
Guest appearances.
On September 4, 1955, Randall and Klugman appeared together with <a href="Gena%20Rowlands">Gena Rowlands</a> in the episode "The Pirate's House" of the <a href="Columbia%20Broadcasting%20Company">CBS</a> <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a> "Appointment with Adventure".
Randall was a frequent guest on "<a href="The%20Tonight%20Show%20Starring%20Johnny%20Carson">The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson</a>" and often spoke of his love of <a href="opera">opera</a> and the salaciousness of many of its plotlines. He also admitted to sneaking tape recorders into operas to make his own private recordings. He chided <a href="Johnny%20Carson">Johnny Carson</a> for his chain smoking and was generally fastidious. At the time of his death, Randall had appeared as a guest on "The Tonight Show" 105 times, more often than any other celebrity had appeared.
Randall appeared frequently on "<a href="What%27s%20My%20Line%3F">What's My Line?</a>", "<a href="Password%20%28American%20game%20show%29">Password</a>", "<a href="The%20Hollywood%20Squares">The Hollywood Squares</a>", and the <a href="Pyramid%20%28game%20show%29">"$10,000" and "$20,000 Pyramids"</a>. He also parodied his pompous image with an appearance as a "contestant" on "<a href="The%20Gong%20Show">The Gong Show</a>" in 1977.
Randall was a guest star on the fifth and final season of "<a href="The%20Muppet%20Show">The Muppet Show</a>" in an episode that first aired on October 11, 1980. This was the 100th episode of the show.
Randall, along with <a href="John%20Goodman">John Goodman</a> and <a href="Drew%20Barrymore">Drew Barrymore</a>, was among the first guests on the debut episode of "<a href="Late%20Night%20with%20Conan%20O%27Brien">Late Night with Conan O'Brien</a>" on September 13, 1993. He would also appear in <a href="Conan%20O%27Brien">Conan O'Brien</a>'s "5th Anniversary Special" with the character PimpBot 5000. Randall was a frequent guest as well on both of <a href="David%20Letterman">David Letterman</a>'s late-night shows "<a href="Late%20Night%20with%20David%20Letterman">Late Night with David Letterman</a>" and the "<a href="Late%20Show%20with%20David%20Letterman">Late Show with David Letterman</a>", making 70 appearances, according to his obituary in "<a href="The%20Washington%20Post">The Washington Post</a>". Letterman said that Randall was one of his favorite guests, along with <a href="Regis%20Philbin">Regis Philbin</a>. 
On November 7, 1994, Randall appeared on the game show "<a href="Jeopardy%21">Jeopardy!</a>", as part of a celebrity episode, playing on behalf of the National Actors Theatre. He came in second place behind General <a href="Norman%20Schwarzkopf%20Jr.">Norman Schwarzkopf Jr.</a> but ahead of actress <a href="Stefanie%20Powers">Stefanie Powers</a>, with a final tally of $9,900.
Other creative activities.
In 1973, Randall and Klugman recorded an album for <a href="London%20Recordings">London Records</a> titled "The Odd Couple Sings". Roland Shaw and the London Festival Orchestra and Chorus provided the music and additional vocals. The record was not a chart-topper but is a highly sought-after item for many "Odd Couple" fans. Randall and Klugman also collaborated on a series of television commercials for Eagle brand snacks.
A noted <a href="Storytelling">raconteur</a>, Randall, along with co-writer Mike Mindlin, wrote a collection of amusing and sometimes racy showbusiness anecdotes called "Which Reminds Me", published in 1989.
In keeping with his penchant for both championing and mocking the culture that he loved, during the <a href="Big%20Band">Big Band</a>-era revival in the mid-1960s, Randall produced a record album of 1930s songs, "Vo Vo De Oh Doe", inspired by (and covering) <a href="the%20New%20Vaudeville%20Band">the New Vaudeville Band</a>'s one-hit wonder, "<a href="Winchester%20Cathedral%20%28song%29">Winchester Cathedral</a>." He mimicked (and somewhat exaggerated) the <a href="vibrato">vibrato</a> style of <a href="Carmen%20Lombardo">Carmen Lombardo</a>, and the two had once sung a duet of Lombardo's signature song "Boo Hoo (You've Got Me Crying for You)" on "<a href="The%20Tonight%20Show">The Tonight Show</a>".
In the 1980s, Randall served as off-camera narrator for several video productions by the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a>, announcing performers to the television audience as they appeared on stage during curtain calls and providing brief descriptions of scenes. 
For the 1990 sequel "", Randall lent his unmistakeable voice to the Brain Gremlin.
Activism.
Randall was an advocate for the arts. During the summer of 1980, he served as the celebrity host of the <a href="New%20York%20Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a> Orchestra's concerts in <a href="Central%20Park">Central Park</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>.
Randall was politically <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a>. He was an active supporter of <a href="Eugene%20McCarthy%201968%20presidential%20campaign">Eugene McCarthy</a> during the <a href="1968%20Democratic%20Party%20presidential%20primaries">1968 Democratic Party presidential primaries</a>. When he was dropped as a regular panelist on the "Opera Quiz" intermission feature of the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera%20radio%20broadcasts">Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts</a> because of his opposition to the <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a>, he donated the remainder of his contract fee to the McCarthy campaign. During the <a href="1972%20Democratic%20Party%20presidential%20primaries">U.S. presidential primaries</a> in <a href="1972%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">1972</a>, he appeared as the <a href="George%20McGovern%201972%20presidential%20campaign">featured celebrity</a> at numerous fundraising house parties for <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a> candidate <a href="George%20McGovern">George McGovern</a>. His name was featured on the <a href="Master%20list%20of%20Nixon%27s%20political%20opponents">master list of Richard Nixon's political opponents</a>.
Personal life.
Randall was married to his high school sweetheart Florence Gibbs from 1938 until her death from cancer on April 18, 1992. The following year, he said, "I wish I believed I'd see my parents again, see my wife again. But I know it's not going to happen." At the age of 75, he married 25-year-old Heather Harlan, an intern at one of his theatrical programs, on November 17, 1995. They lived in a Manhattan apartment and bought a vacation apartment in <a href="Key%20Biscayne%2C%20Florida">Key Biscayne, Florida</a> in 2003. The couple had two children—Julia, born on April 11, 1997, and Jefferson, born on June 15, 1998—and remained married until Randall's death in May 2004.
In his book "Which Reminds Me", Randall maintained that any publicity that an actor generates should be about his work, not himself: "The public knows only one thing about me: I don't smoke."
Death.
Randall passed away in his sleep on May 17, 2004 at <a href="New%20York%20University%20School%20of%20Medicine">NYU Medical Center</a> of <a href="pneumonia">pneumonia</a> that he had contracted following <a href="coronary%20artery%20bypass%20surgery">coronary bypass surgery</a> in December 2003. He had been hospitalized since the operation. His remains are interred at the <a href="Westchester%20Hills%20Cemetery">Westchester Hills Cemetery</a> in <a href="Hastings-on-Hudson%2C%20New%20York">Hastings-on-Hudson</a>, <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a>.
